text: welcome to the amazon translate deep
dive video series
i'm greg rushing from aws and in this
episode we'll be looking at how you can
use the real-time translation feature
with amazon translates neural machine
translation service
this is part one of two in this episode
if you're interested in learning more
about amazon translate please check out
the rest of the videos in this four part
series
communicating effectively with customers
and partners is essential
language gaps can slow or complicate
this process as a feature of your
applications
amazon translate can deliver instant and
on-demand translations of customer
service conversations
to help your agents better serve
international clients with amazon
translate you can perform low latency
translation of up to five thousand bytes
of information with each real-time call
to the service
in this tutorial we'll walk you
step-by-step through the process to
translate text
in real time with the aws command line
interface you can also perform
translations directly in the aws
management console
or with the translate text api via one
of aws sdks
to get started you'll need to set up the
aws cli
on your device for more information on
setting up the cli
please refer to the getting started
section of the developer guide which is
linked below in the description
once you have access to the aws cli
you'll need to ensure your cli config
file contains a user profile with
admin group or translate service
permissions this will ensure you can
access the translate service via the cli
if you need help with this refer to step
two set up the aws command line
interface in the amazon translate
developer guide to configure your cli
appropriately
now that your cli is configured with the
appropriate access level
simply use the translate text operation
to perform your real-time translation
job
use this format to perform your
translation operation
updating the source language code target
language code and text with your
preferred information
after executing the operation you'll
receive a response in json format with
your requested translation output
as you can see here my welcome message
was returned in russian
alternatively you can use the aws cli to
perform a translation operation by using
a json file in the request
to perform this operation you'll first
format the necessary information as a
json file like the one here
then simply input the command in this
format to call the service to perform
the translation
ensure the file name in your command
matches the one that you used for your
json file
in this case the json file that i
created for this demo is named
translate.json
for this type of operation you won't
receive your response in the cli window
but rather you'll have a new file named
translated.json
you can browse to this file to find your
translation result or you can open it in
the cli
using the nano application within your
terminal window
that's it in this tutorial we use the
aws command line interface to perform a
real-time translation with amazon
translate
as we saw you can provide the text you
want to translate as either a parameter
of the translate text operation within a
cli
or by providing the source language
target language and text in a json file
with amazon translate's real-time
translation feature you can add powerful
neural machine translation to your
applications providing your customers
with a local experience no matter where
they are in the world
i hope you enjoyed this tutorial please
check out the other videos in this
series to learn more about amazon
translate
